DataElement.preferredName: International Neuroblastoma Pathology Classification Grade Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term used to describe the classification of neuroblastic differentiation within neuroblastoma tumors, as defined by the International Neuroblastoma Pathology Classification (INPC).

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Neuroblastoma International Neuroblastoma Pathology Classification Histologic Grade
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A neuroblastic tumor characterized by the presence of neuroblastic cells, the absence of ganglion cells, and the absence of a prominent Schwannian stroma formation._A classification system established by adopting the original system proposed by Shimada with subsequent revisions. The INPC distinguishes favorable and unfavorable histology groups._The degree of abnormality of cancer cells, a measure of differentiation, the extent to which cancer cells are similar in appearance and function to healthy cells of the same tissue type. The degree of differentiation often relates to the clinical behavior of the particular tumor. Based on the microscopic findings, tumor grade is commonly described by one of four degrees of severity. Histopathologic grade of a tumor may be used to plan treatment and estimate the future course, outcome, and overall prognosis of disease. Certain types of cancers, such as soft tissue sarcoma, primary brain tumors, lymphomas, and breast have special grading systems.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Neuroblastoma is a specific type of neuroblastic tumor which is characterized by the presense of neuroblastic cells forming groups or nests separated by delicate stromal septa without prominent Schwannian stroma. (Adapted from WHO.)

Concepts.definition: A malignant neuroblastic tumor characterized by the presence of neuroblastic cells, the absence of ganglion cells, and the absence of a prominent Schwannian stroma formation.

Property.preferredName: International Neuroblastoma Pathology Classification Histologic Grade
Property.preferredDefinition: A classification system established by adopting the original system proposed by Shimada with subsequent revisions. The INPC distinguishes favorable and unfavorable histology groups.:The degree of abnormality of cancer cells, a measure of differentiation, the extent to which cancer cells are similar in appearance and function to healthy cells of the same tissue type. The degree of differentiation often relates to the clinical behavior of the particular tumor. Based on the microscopic findings, tumor grade is commonly described by one of four degrees of severity. Histopathologic grade of a tumor may be used to plan treatment and estimate the future course, outcome, and overall prognosis of disease. Certain types of cancers, such as soft tissue sarcoma, primary brain tumors, lymphomas, and breast have special grading systems.

Concepts.definition: A classification system established by adopting the original system proposed by Shimada with subsequent revisions. The INPC distinguishes favorable and unfavorable histology groups.

The degree of abnormality of cancer cells, a measure of differentiation, the extent to which cancer cells are similar in appearance and function to healthy cells of the same tissue type. The degree of differentiation often relates to the clinical behavior of the particular tumor. Based on the microscopic findings, tumor grade is commonly described by one of four degrees of severity. Histopathologic grade of a tumor may be used to plan treatment and estimate the future course, outcome, and overall prognosis of disease. Certain types of cancers, such as soft tissue sarcoma, primary brain tumors, lymphomas, and breast have special grading systems.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics._A position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality._A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A neuroblastoma in which the differentiating neuroblasts constitute more than five-percent of the tumor cells.

Concepts.definition: A neuroblastoma in which the differentiating neuroblasts constitute more than five-percent of the tumor cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A neuroblastoma in which the differentiating neuroblasts constitute less than five-percent of the tumor cells.

Concepts.definition: A neuroblastoma in which the differentiating neuroblasts constitute less than five-percent of the tumor cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A neuroblastoma characterized by the absence of differentiating neuroblasts.

Concepts.definition: A neuroblastoma characterized by the absence of differentiating neuroblasts.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Top level term which includes Biological Markers, Risk Factors, and Prognostic Factors.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Category; used informally to mean a class of things.

Concepts.definition: A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.
